entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments ‚Äì Transition and Future with APIs
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud for Customer Payments - Transition and Future with APIs

SAP has transitioned SAP Cloud for Customer Payments into maintenance mode and removed it from the price list (as of September 2, 2024). The solution will continue to be supported for existing customers under active contracts, but no further development or investments are made. Customers are encouraged to transition to the new API-based approach in SAP S/4HANA Cloud and On-Premise/Private Cloud.

Accounts receivable processes today are often costly, manual, and time-consuming. Many businesses face delays in cash collection, lack of transparency for their customers, and high operational costs for invoice and payment handling.

With the new S/4HANA APIs, SAP enables customers and partners to build modern customer-facing portals that accelerate the invoice-to-cash process and support automated cash collection. These portals empower end customers with self-service capabilities, reducing manual workload while improving the customer experience.

Capabilities Enabled by S/4HANA APIs

Using the APIs already available in S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud businesses can:

APIs for Electronic Bill Presentment and Payment

  • Pay & manage bills: Select open items, create payments (via direct debit or credit card when SAP Digital Payments Add-on is integrated), view or cancel payments in process
  • Display account statements: View and download all items for a specific time period for the customer invoice, credit memo, and / or incoming payment(s)

Other APIs

  • Match payments with invoices: Improve reconciliation through payment matching
  • Create and manage payment advice: Issue or cancel payment advice efficiently
  • Make ad-hoc payments: Support payments on account or down payment requests
  • Manage account master data: View and update account and master data directly

These capabilities can be embedded into custom-built portals or integrated into existing customer-facing portals, offering flexibility for each company‚Äôs unique landscape.

This new API approach is not a one-to-one successor, but provides greater flexibility:

  • APIs are released for S/4HANA On-Premise, Private Cloud, and Public Cloud (from release 2508.02)
  • Customers can build their own portals, integrate into existing ones, or leverage partner-built portals
  • Partners are actively working with SAP to deliver ready-to-use solutions based on these APIs

Partner Solutions: Ready-to-Use Customer Payment Portals

To help customers accelerate adoption, SAP partners already offer pre-built customer payment and self-service portals leveraging the new APIs.

Kumulon ‚Äì KUMOsphere B2B Payment Portal

Kumulon delivers a cloud-native, template-based portal built on SAP BTP with full support for SAP‚Äôs latest payment APIs.

  • Real cloud services, no legacy code ‚Äì innovative SAP Cloud technologies only
  • Flexible templates ‚Äì adapt quickly to customer needs while jumpstarting projects
  • Secure integration ‚Äì SAP Cloud Connector ensures safe on-premise-to-cloud connectivity
  • Flexible deployment ‚Äì operate in your own BTP environment or as SaaS on Kumulon‚Äôs BTP

üîó KUMOsphere ‚Äì B2B Payment Portal on SAP Store

Acuiti Labs ‚Äì Customer Self Care and Payment Portal

Acuiti Labs offers a SaaS-based self-service and payment portal for S/4HANA Private and Public Cloud (Sales Billing/FI-AR) leveraging the S/4HANA APIs.

  • Customer self-service portal ‚Äì empowers end customers to manage invoices and payments directly
  • Cross-solution experience ‚Äì already proven in BRIM (FI-CA), Subscription Billing, and Q2C portals
  • Accelerated go-live ‚Äì prebuilt solution reduces implementation effort

üîó Acuiti Labs Customer Portal on SAP Store

Learn More

APIs for Electronic Billing and Presentment ‚Äì S/4HANA On-Premise (OP), Private Cloud

  • All APIs part of the Electronic Billing and Presentment scope are shipped via SAP Note 3505741
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example: Managing Payment Advice is available, see Payment Advice (A2X).
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

APIs for EBPP Payment Request ‚Äì S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Please see the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for the available EBPP Payment Request APIs.
  • For other required APIs outside the package, please see also the SAP Business Accelerator Hub for more details, for example:
    • Match payments with invoices & Create and manage payment advice, Payment Advice.
    • Make ad-hoc payments, Journal Entry -Post
    • Manage account master data, Business Partner
    • Customer account balance, Accounting Document - Read
  • For more information, visit the SAP Help Portal.

Summary

SAP Cloud for Customer Payments is moving into maintenance mode, and the future lies in API-driven, flexible customer payment portals. Customers can now:

  • Plan their transition to S/4HANA API-based solutions
  • Either build their own portals or leverage ready-to-use partner solutions from the SAP Store

This shift gives businesses greater flexibility, faster innovation, and improved customer experiences in the accounts receivable process.

entry.title: Re: Creating the Shell System for SAP Business Transformation Center: A Practical Approach
entry.content:
Hi @dfunkert

Is there any reason to do the Client Copy by remote?
In my projects we do the following:

1. Do a Systemcopy with SUM DMO without Software Change to migrate form anyDB to SAP HANA
2. create a temp client by copy SAP CUST Profile (or whatever you need) from the customer client on Target.
3. Delete customer client on Target
4. Copy back temp Client to customer client
5. Do the conversion to S4 on the Target so it become your shell

Do you see any issues with this approach?

One additional Info:
SWPM is deprecated for Migrations from anyDB to SAP HANA.
SUM DMO without software change is the tool that should be used.

entry.title: Bridging Project Planning: Integrating SAP Cloud ERP with SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM)
entry.content:
As project-driven organizations increasingly adopt SAP Cloud ERP , the need for robust project planning capabilities becomes critical. While SAP Cloud ERP excels in financial, commercial and logistics aspects of project management, SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM) complements the SAP Business Suite‚Äîoffering scheduling, resource allocation, and project structure capabilities.

This blog provides details on integration relevant features that enables intelligent project execution by importing projects from SAP Cloud ERP into PRM and then proceed with further detailed project planning and scheduling. 

Integration Setup

PRM supports integration with Enterprise Projects as well as Professional Service Projects. There are two ways to integrate with SAP Cloud ERP for the purpose of project planning, execution and scheduling.

  1. Use the recommended approach i.e. Direct Point-Point Integration.
  2. Alternatively, you can establish the integration using SAP Integration Suite.

For organizations evaluating integration options between SAP Cloud ERP and SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM), it's important to understand the advantages of each approach and why the direct point-to-point integration is recommended.

Direct Point-to-Point Integration offers seamless synchronization of project data using the Enterprise Project API. This method ensures that project information is always up-to-date between SAP Cloud ERP and PRM, reducing manual data entry and the risk of errors. It supports both enterprise and professional services projects and enables full project management capabilities within PRM, including editing and scheduling of imported project plans. Customers benefit from a streamlined process, improved data accuracy, and the ability to leverage advanced planning  and scheduling features offered by PRM, making it ideal for organizations seeking an integrated and efficient project management workflow.

Integration via SAP Integration Suite provides flexibility for more complex or hybrid system landscapes, especially when connecting to SAP Cloud ERP Private. While this approach may suit organizations with specific middleware or integration requirements, it currently supports only the import of project plans through the ‚ÄúManage Multiple Project Plans‚Äù application. This means that imported plans cannot be edited or scheduled within PRM, potentially limiting the depth of project management and planning capabilities available to users.

In summary, customers using SAP Cloud ERP should choose the recommended direct point-to-point integration because it delivers comprehensive project management functions, enables bi-directional data exchange, and ensures optimal use of PRM‚Äôs planning and scheduling tools. The SAP Integration Suite option may be considered for specialized cases but comes with functional limitations that may impact project execution and flexibility.

Detailed Overview 

This section offers a step-by-step walkthrough of the key features that enable project plan integration between SAP Project and Resource Management (PRM) and SAP Cloud ERP, accessible via the ‚ÄúManage Project Plans‚Äù application.

Pre-requisite:

  • You have created either an Enterprise Project with a high level project plan or a PSA Project with few work packages added to it, in SAP Cloud ERP.
  • You have created a Collaborative Project in PRM which we would use further in this blog.

 The next step is to import the Enterprise or PSA Project in SAP Cloud ERP as a project plan within the Collaborative Project in PRM

In ‚ÄúManage Project Plans‚Äù application, start creating a project plan for your Collaborative Project by choosing the option ‚Äú From Other System‚Äù.

In the pop-up window, the Collaborative Project gets defaulted from the previous selection. The ‚ÄúSource System‚Äù field should be showing already the SAP Cloud ERP system that‚Äôs configured as active in Business System Configuration application. In case of multiple SAP Cloud ERP systems configured in PRM as active, you can select the one from the drop down list from which you want to import the project.

By default, the ‚ÄúRelated Object‚Äù(Created in Collaborative Project) checkbox field is selected. When you click on ‚ÄúGo‚Äù, the system shows a list of projects based on the Related Objects of object type ‚ÄúProject‚Äù that you would have created earlier for the collaborative project as shown in the ‚ÄúRelated Objects‚Äù screenshot below. This allows you to quickly choose a project from the list without searching for it and proceed with project plan creation

If there are no Related Objects created prior to this step, then you can deselect the ‚ÄúRelated Object‚Äù(Created in Collaborative Project) checkbox and start to search the projects by choosing the value help provided for ‚ÄúProject from Source System‚Äù. You can type in a search term which can either be the project ID or Name . Select a project and click on ‚ÄúContinue‚Äù

Hint : While searching projects, the system uses ‚ÄúEnterprise Project‚Äù API to communicate with the corresponding source SAP Cloud ERP system and hence the list would show both Professional Services projects as well as Enterprise Projects.

In the next screen, system shows a preview of things that will be done by the system. Choose ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù to finish importing the project as a project plan in PRM.

You can see that the project structure(Work Packages and Milestones) from the source system has been imported along with the scheduling relevant information like Planned Start , Planned Finish dates . The duration field shows the calculated number of days between the start and finish dates.

Navigation links to Source System

If the project that you imported is an Enterprise Project, you can navigate to the corresponding Project Briefs app or the WBS Element by clicking on the hyperlink provided for each element in the project structure

If the project that you imported is a Professional Services Project, the project structure would contain the relevant Work Packages and Billing Elements. You can navigate to the corresponding project in the ‚ÄúProject Control- Professional Services Projects‚Äù application by clicking on relevant hyperlinks in the project structure.

Keeping PRM and SAP Cloud ERP Projects in Sync

When you Edit Project Plan in the Manage Project Plans app, the system first validates whether any incremental changes have been made to the corresponding source project in the SAP Cloud ERP system by any user. If such updates exist, the user is prompted to Receive Updates before proceeding, ensuring that the version being edited reflects the latest data from the source project.

The Sync Actions button in the Manage Project Plans app provides three key options that control how schedule data is exchanged between systems.

  • Receive Updates ‚Äì pulls the latest project structure information from the source project in SAP Cloud ERP into PRM, ensuring that the project plan in PRM reflects the most current version.
  • Send Updates ‚Äì pushes date changes made in PRM. Ideally this is not needed to be used until there are some error situations in date synchronization, in which case the user will be shown the messages in the project plan application.
  • Check Send Status ‚Äì allows project managers to verify the transmission results and monitor whether the synchronization of dates has been successfully completed. In case of error situations, error message is shown in the project plan header of this application. For more details on this, refer this troubleshooting section in PRM user guide.

Now let‚Äôs do some edits to the project plan. Change Project Plan start  date. Add some dependencies between the work packages or milestones by establishing Finish-Start Relationships.

Change project plan settings to scheduling to ‚ÄúForward Scheduling‚Äù for example. And then click on ‚ÄúSchedule‚Äù to schedule the project with forward scheduling settings. The dates must have changed for some of the project elements. Once editing is complete and the project plan is saved, any changes made to project plan header or any Work Package (Planned Start, Planned Finish, Actual Start, and Actual Finish dates) or any Milestone(Planned Finish, Actual Finish, and Forecast Finish dates) , either manually or through the Schedule function‚Äîare automatically synchronized back to the source project in SAP Cloud ERP.

You can click on ‚ÄúSync Actions‚Äù->‚ÄùCheck Send Status‚Äù to verify that the project plan is synchronized with source system. System should show a toast message as shown in screenshot below.

You can verify that the changes are reflected in SAP Cloud ERP system in ‚ÄúProject Planning‚Äù application as shown above.

This bi-directional synchronization ensures that both systems remain aligned, supporting consistent and accurate project scheduling across platforms.

Processing Status

In the Manage Project Plans app, the ability to edit project element dates depends on the processing status of the corresponding project in SAP Cloud ERP. You can notice that the processing status from the source project is also brought into the project plan and is shown both in the Project Plan Header and also at the Work package or Milestone level in the project structure. You can modify planned, actual, and forecast dates for both Enterprise Projects and Professional Services Projectswhen the project or the work package has processing status such as Created, Released, Partially Released, In Planning, In Contract Preparation, or In Execution. However, once a project reaches a Completed, Closed, or Locked status, editing of the work package or the milestone under it is no longer allowed.

Conclusion :

By integrating PRM with SAP Cloud ERP, customers can now achieve a truly unified project management experience that enables seamless coordination between planning and execution. This integration facilitates close monitoring of project timelines and milestones, while also providing precise control over project costs and material demands directly within the connected ERP system. As a result, organizations benefit from enhanced visibility, improved resource allocation, and the ability to respond swiftly to changes, ensuring projects are delivered on time and within budget. The synchronized data flow between platforms not only reduces manual effort but also supports informed decision-making, ultimately driving operational efficiency and better business outcomes.

Related API:

Project Plan Service API - to import project from SAP Cloud ERP into PRM:  
For detailed information, refer to the Business Accelerator Hub. 

Related Topics:  

  • Must Start On & Must Finish On Constraints: Define specific constraints on project elements, offering more precise control over scheduling and enhancing project flexibility. - To learn more, see this link: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/date-constraints-in-sap-... 
  • Schedule Projects with SAP Project and Resource Management : To learn more, see this link https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-blog-posts-by-sap/schedule-projects-with-sap-project-and-resource-management/ba-p/14137576?emcs_t=S2h8ZW1haWx8a3Vkb3N8TUY4MjBUNEZERk9LQkR8MTQxMzc1NzZ8S1VET1N8aEs

Discover more by checking out our website.

entry.title: Prevent approval/rejection of forwarded workflow task when user lacks required profiles
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

We have a requirement to prevent users who received a forwarded workflow task in My Inbox from approving or rejecting the task if they do not have the required authorization profiles.

To achieve this, we implemented the BAdI /IWWRK/IF_WF_WI_BEFORE_UPD_IB.
Our logic works correctly in principle ‚Äî it checks the user‚Äôs profiles and returns an error message in CT_RETURN if the authorization is missing. However, the task still gets completed regardless of the error message.

We have noticed that there are standard SAP implementations of this BAdI which already execute the work item before our implementation is called. As a result, even when we return an error message, the action still goes through and the work item is disappears from the inbox.

Question:

Is there a supported way to prevent or cancel the work item execution if our custom implementation detects missing authorization? Or is there a more appropriate BAdI or method (for flexible workflows) where such pre-checks can be implemented?

Any guidance or experience from others who have handled similar requirements would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your help!

Anouk

entry.title: Re: Test Suite Dashboard - Custom Fields Implementation
entry.content:
My experience: The usual Mario Jump&Run.

I had two custom fields and created four entries for them: two for DEFECTSTAT and two for DEFECTSTPR.

The generation failed with the useless error message 'Error activating append structure'. So what? I debugged the generation and discovered that the error was reported by FM DDIF_TABL_ACTIVATE for the fourth customizing entry. Indeed structure /SALM/DASH_DETAILS_DEFPRG_CUST was missing the second append. Hm.

 I logoff and login again, and - o wonder - now the structure /SALM/DASH_DETAILS_DEFPRG_CUST had both appends, and the generation was successful.

I had to delete the cache with transaction /IWFND/CACHE_CLEANUP.

But the Test Suite Dashboard showed an empty screen. I looked into transaction /IWFND/ERROR_LOG and found the error message, that the data object of the first custom field already exists.

OK, the IMG documentation told "Field Name: define the unique technical field name of the property" but did not specify the frame of the uniqueness. The maintenance view of the "Properties" table suggests that the key is View/Field Name. Now I understand that "Field Name" has to be unique independently of the View, because they are all thrown into the same service.

I deleted the two entries for DEFECTSTPR and generated again, but [obviously üôÇ - I know SAP ...] the deletion of the customizing did not delete the appends. So I had to delete the appends manually with SE11 (and I also cleaned the trasnport task).

Now I created the two entries for DEFECTSTPR adding a suffix to the field name and generated: Same procedure. First a generation error, then, after logoff and login again a successful generation. After deleting the Model Cache the Test Suite Dashboard showed finally up, and the fields were there.

But obviously still not perfect working. Because one of the two fields has a list of fixed values in the domain. In the Defect App and in the Mass Change the value help works. But not here in the Test Suite ALP. As there is no documentation I just tried out all four filter types (VS, VM, LS, LM) but no one worked. I will create a Case in Sap4Me.

entry.title: Switching Between Old and New Performance Management Form UI ‚Äì Impact on Existing Forms?
entry.content:
Dear all,

As part of the releases for Performance & Goals Management, we have a question regarding the feature ‚ÄúEnabling Latest Experience of Performance Management Forms.‚Äù

We are running two performance processes:

  • Process 1 should use the old UI.
  • Process 2 should use the new UI.

The new UI can be activated by checking ‚ÄúEnabling Latest Experience of Performance Management Forms‚Äù under Performance Management Feature Settings. Once this option is enabled, the UI of the forms immediately switches from old to new.

Our question:
Is it possible to switch the UI back and forth by simply checking or unchecking this option, even if forms have already been launched? Or does changing the UI have any impact on existing forms or other technical implications we should be aware of?

The two processes run sequentially: first the process with the old UI, then the process with the new UI.

Thank you in advance for your support!

Best Regards,
Joe

entry.title: Re: How to batch upload G/L accounts in S/4 Public Cloud...
entry.content:
Good day @Grace_Li1 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Manage G/L Account Master Data, Download Templates, General Ledger Accounting, Chart of Accounts (Two-System Landscape)

To summarise, in public cloud, you can only create and carry out mass maintenance of G/L accounts through the Excel upload functionality in the Manage G/L Accounts Master Data.

However, this upload supports only certain master data attributes such as account number, name, type, and group assignment. It does not allow updating system-controlled or sensitive flags like ‚ÄúNot Used‚Äù or others in bulk as you intend to. Therefore, it explains the limitation you are experiencing.

The clean-core approach in public cloud aims to ensure data integrity and audit compliance, which is also another factor in play here.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Assistance Required in Connecting to SAP S/4HANA OData Service via External Clients (Postman / Appli
entry.content:
Dear SAP Support Team,

I am currently working on establishing an external connection to our SAP S/4HANA system using OData APIs, as part of an application integration requirement.

I have already identified the OData service endpoint using the SAP transaction/n/IWFND/MAINT_SERVICEand successfully activated the service. The OData service functions correctly from within the SAP Logon / SAP GUI environment, confirming that the service itself is active and reachable from the internal SAP side.

However, I am facing difficulties when attempting to access the same OData endpoint using Postman (and subsequently from my application). The connection attempt either times out or fails to find the host.

Below are the current details and findings:

Details:

  • SAP System Type: S/4HANA

  • Service Activation: Done via /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE

  • Service Status: Active and working when accessed within SAP GUI

  • OData URL (sample):
    https://<host>:<port>/sap/opu/odata/sap/<SERVICE_NAME>/

  • Authentication Types I want to test:

entry.title: Clarification on ‚ÄúE/R key diff. balance‚Äù Field in FCV App (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition)
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

In the Foreign Currency Valuation (FCV) app in S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, there is a field called ‚ÄúE/R key diff. balance‚Äù (Exchange Rate Key Difference Balance) under the G/L Account Balances tab.

Purpose / Usage As per my understanding-
This field allows you to specify a G/L account that will store the exchange rate difference balance during the foreign currency valuation process.
When FCV runs, SAP recalculates the value of foreign currency balances based on the key date‚Äôs exchange rate.
If the rate has changed, the system identifies a gain or loss. Normally, these are posted to gain/loss accounts, but for certain balance sheet accounts (like bank or intercompany accounts), you may want to record revaluation differences separately. That‚Äôs where this field is used.

How It Works As per my understanding-
When maintained, the system posts the valuation difference (gain/loss) to the G/L account entered in this field instead of adjusting the main G/L balance ‚Äî keeping the operational balance and valuation effect clearly separated.

Key Benefits:

  • Keeps FX valuation effects separate for better transparency and auditability
  • Simplifies reconciliation and reporting

Also, as I understand, the setup comes from SSCUI 100297 ‚Äì ‚ÄúDefine Accounts for Exchange Rate Differences‚Äù under Auto Account Determination, where keys like Z001 are defined and linked to the relevant G/L accounts.

I just want to validate if this understanding of benefit and configuration is correct and whether there are any additional uses or best practices for this field in Public Cloud.

Thank you for your guidance in advance

Best regards,

Rohini Dutta

entry.title: Re: Lets Send multipart/form-data to external Receiver: CPI to AI App
entry.content:
Hello,

I think, it is more adequate/easy to use a standard library like apache http to obtain the desired results.

Here is a groovy script which produces multipart/form-data for http post of binary file data together with json (change  names of entities as needed):

(I used httpclient5-5.5.1.jar and httpcore5-5.3.5.jar) 

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

import org.apache.hc.client5.http.entity.mime.MultipartEntityBuilder;
import org.apache.hc.core5.http.HttpEntity;
import org.apache.hc.core5.http.ContentType;


def Message processData(Message message) {

def filename = message.getProperty("fileName") as String;

String body = message.getBody();
//get base64 encoded body, decode it as byte array
byte[] barry = org.apache.commons.codec.binary.Base64.decodeBase64(body);
//get json
def jsonReqest = message.getProperty("JsonRequest") as String;
//setup multipart
MultipartEntityBuilder builder = MultipartEntityBuilder.create();
//add json as text entity 
builder.addTextBody("requestData", jsonReqest, ContentType.APPLICATION_JSON);
//add file as binary entity
builder.addBinaryBody("fileContent", barry, ContentType.APPLICATION_OCTET_STREAM, filename);

HttpEntity entity = builder.build();
//set multipart/form-data header
message.setHeader("Content-Type", entity.getContentType());


message.setBody(entity.getContent());

return message;

}

entry.title: Re: Feasibility Check on DMS Integration Requirement
entry.content:
Hello @Maheshk123 

Thank you for your question.

In summary, you can technically integrate attachments from external systems such as Kissflow into SAP DMS. However, because of the public cloud clean-core approach, there are restrictions to directly access the backend file repositories. This means that you must carry out the integration through standard APIs or BTP-based connectors and not by writing directly into SAP tables or content servers.

The clean-core and supported approach in public cloud is for you to leverage SAP DMS through BTP and combine them with the Attachment API available on the Business HUB.

Have a look at the following references for further details.

Documents Integration, Integrating with SAP Document Management Service, Attachments (A2X), DMS-5695: Integration with external systems, Connecting SAP Document Management Service

 

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Re-Test (Inspection) Date calc
entry.content:
Hi,
By default, SAP calculates the retest date based on the Goods Receipt (GR) date plus the inspection interval. To make the system calculate it from the Manufacturing Date, you need to configure batch management and quality management settings so that the production date (MFG date) is used as the reference instead of GR. This typically requires customizing in batch master data, inspection lot creation, or enhancement via user exits/BAdIs.

entry.title: Re: Automatic create STO from SO
entry.content: In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, automatic creation of a Stock Transport Order from a Sales Order is not a standard ‚Äúout‚Äëof‚Äëthe‚Äëbox‚Äù function. To achieve this, you need to configure cross‚Äëplant stock determination and supply assignment so that when the sales order is confirmed in plant 11DC, the system recognizes stock availability in plant 11DA and triggers a replenishment process (via purchase requisition ‚Üí STO). This typically requires Advanced ATP (aATP) with Alternative Plant Assignment and MRP‚Äëbased STO creation rather than a direct SD‚Äëto‚ÄëMM link.

entry.title: Re: Change existing stock items from Non-Batch to Batch M...
entry.content:
Hi,
In SAP, you cannot simply switch a material from non-batch-managed to batch-managed if stock already exists ‚Äî SAP requires that all stock be cleared first. Without batch management, the only way to track each product individually is to use serial number management instead of batch management

SAP restriction: Once stock exists for a material, you cannot activate batch management in the material master until that stock is consumed or cleared.

Standard process: Clear unrestricted and reserved stock. Change material master to batch managed. Re-post stock with batch numbers (via MIGO).

This is why your scenario (with 300 materials and 8000 finished products) is problematic ‚Äî clearing stock is not feasible

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Factoring Process witho...
entry.content:
Hi @byd ,

I've not used this flow - but did some research for app equivalences etc. and the output is as below. Please review carefully for your scenario to see if it gets you what you need:

Corrected App Mapping:

  • Customer Invoicing: Use "Create Customer Invoice" app (not F-22)
  • Manual Journal Entry: Use "Create Journal Entry" app (replaces FB01)
  • Incoming Payments: Use "Post Incoming Payments" app (replaces F-28)
  • Outgoing Payments: Use "Post Outgoing Payments" app (replaces F-53)
  • Manual Clearing: Use "Clear G/L Account" app (replaces F1579)

Detailed Implementation Steps

Step 1: Invoice Creation (Feb 10)

  • App: Create Customer Invoice
  • Posting:
    • DR: Customer Account ¬•1,000,000
    • CR: Revenue Account ¬•1,000,000

Step 2: Factoring Transaction (Mar 10)

  • App: Create Journal Entry
  • Posting:
    • DR: Bank Account ¬•900,000
    • DR: Factoring Fee Expense ¬•100,000
    • CR: Customer Account ¬•1,000,000
  • Note: This directly clears the customer AR while recording the factoring fee

Step 3: Customer Payment Receipt (Apr 15)

  • App: Create Journal Entry (not Post Incoming Payments)
  • Posting:
    • DR: Bank Account ¬•1,000,000
    • CR: Deposits Payable/Trust Account ¬•1,000,000
  • Rationale: Since the AR is already cleared, use journal entry rather than incoming payments

Step 4: Transfer to Factoring Company (Apr 16)

  • App: Post Outgoing Payments or Create Journal Entry
  • Posting:
    • DR: Deposits Payable ¬•1,000,000
    • CR: Bank Account ¬•1,000,000

Key Considerations

Account Setup Requirements:

  • Create a "Deposits Payable" or "Trust Account" G/L account
  • Set up a "Factoring Fee Expense" G/L account
  • Ensure proper bank account configuration for multiple cash flows

Process Validation:

  • The manual journal entry in Step 2 can indeed clear customer-specific AR directly
  • No additional clearing process needed if postings are structured correctly
  • Consider implementing approval workflows for manual journal entries

Alternative Approach: If direct AR clearing via journal entry faces restrictions, consider:

  1. Use "Post Incoming Payments" in Step 2 with a clearing account
  2. Post the factoring fee separately via journal entry
  3. Use clearing functions to match the transactions

entry.title: Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages
entry.content:
A new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages has been recently shipped. This is the first increment of the newly split up packages. I hope you remember, with the last update we decided to split up the now deprecated package into 4 packages to better support the setup of multiple pipelines, see New integration packages for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration.

At that point of time we replaced the scripts from the script collection with local scripts and deprecated the script collection since this was part of the deprecated package anyway. Using local scripts in the generic flow gives us more flexibility in setting up multiple pipelines. However, for the scripts in the provided templates we received feedback that customers prefer to have a script collection because scenario-specific flows are built as copy of the templates and if the local scripts need to be updated then this would result into high maintenance effort. So, we decided to provide a new script collection at least for the templates. This script collection is shipped with the templates package and the templates that uses scripts have been updated to use the scripts from the script collection. If you have scenario-specific flows that either use the old script collection or the local scripts, you need to replace them with the new script collection. Sorry for the inconvenience, but you have to update your existing scenario-specific flows that use scripts anyway because for the new script collection we had to define a new ID.

Besides this change, the new version comes with a couple of new features based on customer demand. The new features are as follows:

  • We now support a generic IDoc outbound flow to standardize and ease the configuration of IDoc outbound scenarios.
  • We now support a generic XI outbound flow to standardize and ease the configuration of XI outbound scenarios.
  • We have improved the support for sender and receiver parties.
  • We have improved the support for receiver-specific queues and the definition of the queue for receiver-specific outbound processing.
  • In a sender wildcard scenario, we now support inbound conversion per sender.
  • Non-XML payloads are encoded before storing in an exchange property to avoid that the payload gets corrupted when reading from the exchange property again.
  • For some scenarios, you have the option to run scenarios in the pipeline without the need of the Partner Directory.

If you like to leverage the new features, you need to update all 4 packages. If you already use the pipeline, your packages are labeled with update available, also for those packages that you created as copy with suffix.

Generic IDoc outbound flow

For scenarios in which Cloud Integration connects to receiver systems exchanging IDoc messages, you can use the generic outbound integration flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for IDoc from the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound.

You can setup the generic IDoc outbound either using one single generic IDoc outbound integration flow across all your receiving systems or using one generic IDoc outbound integration flow for each receiving system. In any case, the generic IDoc outbound integration flow allows you to setup your IDoc outbound scenarios in a common way including built-in support for guaranteed delivery and error handling.

Because we use a generic flow across multiple scenarios, the IDoc receiver adapter parameters and the IDoc control headers are dynamically set during runtime. Here, the following configuration options are supported:

  • Configuring externalized parameters of the generic IDoc outbound integration flow.
  • Maintaining the parameters in the Partner Directory.
  • Creating message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.
  • Defining the IDoc control header in the message body in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For more details about the configuration options, refer to the XI Receiver Adapter chapter in the help documentation.

Generic XI outbound flow

For scenarios in which Cloud Integration connects to receiver systems using the XI message protocol, you can use the generic outbound integration flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI from the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. Here, the generic XI outbound flow supports both asynchronous as well as synchronous communication.

Like for the generic IDoc outbound, you can setup the generic XI outbound either using one single generic XI outbound integration flow across all your receiving systems or using one generic XI outbound integration flow for each receiving system.

The XI receiver adapter parameters and the XI header attributes are dynamically set during runtime. The following configuration options are supported:

  • Configuring externalized parameters of the generic XI outbound integration flow.
  • Maintaining Partner Directory parameters.
  • Maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For more details about the configuration options, refer to the IDoc Receiver Adapter in the help documentation.

Sender and receiver parties

Scenarios with sender and receiver parties are better supported now. We decided to go for a simplified approach by concatenating the party name if any with the sender or receiver component name. The headers SAP_Sender and SAP_Receiver show the concatenated names in the message monitor. In addition to this, we create new headers SAP_SenderParty and SAP_ReceiverParty which can be used in the subsequent flows, especially this is needed for the XI outbound.

If you have a sender party, in the Partner Directory maintain the alternative partner of the configuration scenario as follows: define the agency as a combination of the sender party and the sender component name separated by a dot.

If you have a receiver party, define the receiver service name within the XSLT that you run to determine the receiver and the receiver interface as combination of the receiver party and the receiver component name separated by a dot.

When running the scenario, in the message processing log, the sender and receiver information is displayed as follows:

  • The Sender and the Receiver in the Properties section show the concatenated party/component names.
  • Custom header properties SenderParty and ReceiverParty are added showing the party names.
  • Custom header properties SenderSystem and ReceiverSystem are added showing the component names, here the actual business system names depending on the landscape stage in case that you use the landscape staging feature.
  • If you use the landscape staging feature, and your actual business system differ from the alias names used within the pipeline, the alias names SenderAlias and ReceiverAlias are added as custom header properties.

Receiver-specific queues

By default, each scenario uses the same set of generic JMS queues. For receivers for which you want to control the outbound delivery, you can define receiver-specific JMS queues. So far, this was done for a particular receiver. Now, you can define a dedicated queue for a particular receiver and for  a particular scenario. For latter, you can define different receiver-specific queues for the same receiver depending on your particular configuration scenario. The scenario-specific setting overrides the global setting.

If you like to use a receiver-specific JMS outbound queue across all your scenarios, create a partner in the Partner Directory with the partner ID equaling the business system name and a string parameter with ID ReceiverSpecificQueue. As value, enter the receiver-specific queue name.

If you like to define a receiver-specific JMS outbound queue for a particular configuration scenario only, define a corresponding string parameter for the partner ID representing your configuration scenario. In this case, the string parameter ID is a combination of the constant identifier ReceiverSpecificQueue and the business system name separated with an underscore "_". As value, enter the scenario/receiver-specific queue name.

For each receiver-specific queue, you need to copy the generic outbound processing flow and configure the JMS queue name accordingly. Don't directly copy, instead copy the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound from the Discover Artifacts area of your tenant. This way, the copied flow is still receiving the regular updates if any. As you can see in the screenshot below, we have improved the JMS queue maintenance to be more flexible in defining receiver-specific queues. Besides the prefix you can now also define a suffix. By default, the suffix is empty. The JMS queue name is then concatenated using the prefix, the constant Q04 and the suffix.

And here we go. If you run the scenario, the receivers Receiver_11 and Receiver_12 use the queue defined in the scenario whereas receiver Receiver_13 uses the one defined in the business system.

Inbound conversion

To determine whether your specific scenario needs an inbound conversion, you create a string parameter holding the ProcessDirect endpoint of your scenario-specific inbound conversion flow. So far, you could only define one inbound conversion per scenario. In a sender wildcard scenario, i.e., a scenario in which the same configuration applies to different sender systems, you may have the requirement to define different inbound conversions depending on the sender system. This is supported now.

If you need inbound conversion and you only have one sender for your configuration scenario, create one scenario-specific inbound conversion flow and configure the string parameter InboundConversionEndpoint in the Partner Directory pointing to the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific integration flow.

In case of sender wildcard scenarios, you have two options. If your inbound conversion is the same for each sender system, you only need to create one single scenario-specific inbound conversion flow and hence only have to maintain one configuration parameter InboundConversionEndpoint. If the inbound conversion differs depending on the sender systems, you need to create scenario-specific inbound conversion flows for each sender system and hence have the option to maintain a configuration parameter for each sender system as combination of the constant term InboundConversionEndpoint and the sender system name separated by underscore "_". The system-specific parameter overrules the scenario-specific parameter.

When running the scenario, you can see that the business system BS_DD2_Q with system alias BS_DD2 uses the sender-specific inbound conversion.

Extension for scenario configuration

If you prefer not to use the Partner Directory, you have the option to configure most of the parameters defining your configuration scenario as custom parameters in your scenario-specific inbound processing flows. The custom parameters are passed to the generic pipeline flows and if present the Partner Directory is not called.

For more details about the alternative scenario configuration, see Run Pipeline for Cloud Integration without the Partner Directory.

entry.title: Run Pipeline for Cloud Integration without the Partner Directory
entry.content:
With the new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages, we have added the possibility to configure your configuration scenario without the need of the Partner Directory. If you prefer not to use the Partner Directory, you have the option to configure most of the parameters defining your configuration scenario as custom headers in your scenario-specific inbound processing flows. The custom headers are passed to the generic pipeline flows and if present the Partner Directory is not called.

As you may know, the Pipeline for Cloud Integration is not yet supported on Edge Integration Cell due to the missing support for the Partner Directory on Edge Integration Cell. We do have the support for the Partner Directory on Edge Integration Cell in our roadmap, see Support for the partner directory, but as long as it is not supported you may try out the Pipeline on Edge Integration Cell already today. And once this is shipped, you can switch to the Partner Directory and then leverage the full feature scope of the Pipeline.

With this extension, not all scenarios and features are supported. For instance, we do not support XI and IDoc inbound scenarios because here we do not have an option to define the custom headers in the inbound. Furthermore, we do not support tenant staging and receiver specific outbound queues because here a call to the Partner Directory would be needed.

Also, for content-based-router and recipient list patterns, we can't read an XSLT from the Partner Directory which is the standard approach to carry out the XPath conditions to determine receivers and interfaces. Instead you need to apply custom receiver and interface determination, i.e., calling a custom integration flow where you determine the receivers and interfaces. For this you have different options like running a message mapping or an XSLT, and lately we have shipped options using groovy scripts, see New templates for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: enhancing the custom receiver determination.

Besides those templates, we also provide a more generic template Pipeline v2 Template Step04 - Custom Receiver Determination in the templates package that you can copy and then upload any message mapping or XSLT. An option would be using the Partner Directory Accelerator Tool for Pipeline Concept to create the XSLT by maintaining the XPath conditions in the accelerator tool. This way, the switch to the Partner Directory once supported would be easier because you can then simply reuse the XSLT.

As mentioned above, for bypassing the Partner Directory you need to define custom headers in the scenario-specific inbound flow. Besides other headers, headers starting with customX are in the allowed list of the generic flows and hence can be passed to the generic flows.

For compatibility reasons, it's mandatory to create the header partnerID. If the header exists, the generic pipeline won't try to map the sender component name and the sender interface name to a partner ID in the Partner Directory. Otherwise, your message will fail.

Let's configure and deploy two different scenarios on Edge Integration Cell, one Content-Based-Router and one Point-to-Point scenario. We will only use the integrated messaging runtime, so we just have to deploy the two generic flows Pipeline v2 Generic Step02 - Integrated Messaging Runtime Async and Pipeline v2 Generic Step06 - Outbound Processing on Edge Integration Cell.

 

Content-Based-Router

To run a Content-Based-Router scenario on Edge Integration Cell, we need to create an integration flow which is called to determine the receivers and interfaces. As proposed above, we created the integration flow as copy of the generic custom receiver determination template and used the XSLT from the Partner Directory, i.e., we downloaded the XSLT from the Partner Directory, and imported it as reference to the integration flow.

Next, we need to configure the configuration scenario in the scenario-specific inbound flow.

In a content modifier step, the following mandatory message headers need to be created:

  • partnerID with value equals the configuration scenario name.
  • customXRDEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom receivers and interfaces integration flow, see above.
 
Because this scenario needs an inbound conversion to convert the incoming message from JSON to XML, we have to create an inbound conversion integration flow, and hence have to create the header customXInboundConversionEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the integration flow performing the inbound conversion.

In addition, we created the following optional headers:

  • maxJMSRetries to define a scenario-specific maximum number of retries overriding the default value which is 5. In our case we changed the value to 1.
  • customXPreEnabled specifying the pipeline steps for which we like to call a custom pre-processing flow, in our case for both generic pipeline steps (02 stands for the integrated messaging runtime, and 06 stands for the generic outbound processing). See New feature for the Pipeline for Cloud Integration: custom preprocessing exit.
  • customXPreEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom pre-processing flow.

Once, all integration flows have been deployed on the Edge Integration Cell runtime, we can run the scenario. As you can see in the screenshot below, the custom receiver determination flow has been called. Furthermore, for both pipeline steps the custom preprocessing flow has been called.

 

Point-to-Point

Now, let's setup an asynchronous Point-to-Point (P2P) scenario where most of the pipeline is actually bypassed. For this, we need to create a scenario-specific inbound flow and a scenario-specific outbound flow. The scenario-specific inbound flow directly calls the generic outbound processing flow so that the message is persisted in the JMS queue to ensure restart and Exactly Once delivery. The generic outbound processing flow then delivers the message to the scenario-specific outbound flow.

In the scenario-specific inbound flow, we create the following mandatory headers:

  • partnerID with value equals the configuration scenario name.
  • SAP_OutboundProcessingEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound flow. This header is passed to the generic outbound processing flow which then sends the message to the corresponding scenario-specific outbound flow.

In addition, we created the following optional headers:

  • SAP_Receiver holding the name of the receiver system. This can be added to show up in the message monitor.
  • maxJMSRetries to define a scenario-specific maximum number of retries overriding the default value.
  • customXPreEnabled specifying the pipeline steps for which we like to call a custom pre-processing flow. For P2P, we only use the generic outbound processing, i.e., pipeline step number 06.
  • customXPreEndpoint with value equals the ProcessDirect endpoint of the custom pre-processing flow.

Once, all integration flows have been deployed on Edge Integration Cell, we can run the scenario.

For more details, see Custom Scenario Configuration.

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Announcing Recurring Block Times
entry.content:
Version

VersionDateChanges
1.014.11.2025Initial Version - Daily Recurrence for Test Tenants

 

Introduction

Efficient dock scheduling is critical for smooth logistics operations. SAP Business Network for Logistics (BN4L) Dock Appointment Scheduling is constantly evolving to meet the needs of modern supply chains. Today, we‚Äôre excited to announce the new Recurring Block Times feature which will be first time available with the 2511 (Nov 15th, 2025) release for Test Tenants.


Feature Availability

The Recurring Block Times feature will be available for Test Tenants with the upcoming 2511 release of SAP Business Network for Logistics Dock Appointment Scheduling.

Outlook:

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • Release 2512/2601 Test Tenants:  
    • Extend recurring block times for weekly and monthly recurrences
    • Further Improvements on the existing functionality
  • Release 2602 Production Tenants:
    • Planned feature availably for productive tenants


What Are Recurring Block Times?

Recurring Block Times allow logistics managers to automatically block specific time slots on a recurring basis‚Äîsuch as every Monday morning or the first Friday of each month. This feature is ideal for:

  • Regular maintenance windows
  • Reserved periods for priority shipments
  • Staff meetings or training sessions
  • Public holidays or company events
  • etc.


New Feature ‚ÄúRecurring Block Time‚Äù

  • Creation of blocker series (2511 Daily Recurrence) in Manage Entities App for a Loading Point
  • Block specific capacity of a loading point or block the maximum capacity including overbooking across validity periods. Please see SAP Business Network for Logistics - Dock Appointment Scheduling: Maximum Capacity Blocker
  • Capacity check if the slot capacity exceeds the capacity of the validity period defined for the loading point
  • Release single Blocks from the series from Manage Dock Appointment App


Key Benefits

  • Automated Planning: Set up recurring blocks once and let the system manage future reservations.
  • Reduced Scheduling Conflicts: Prevent accidental bookings during blocked periods.
  • Improved Resource Allocation: Ensure resources are available when needed most.
  • Flexible Adjustments: Easily modify or remove recurring blocks as business needs change.


How to Use Recurring Block Times

  1. Access the Manage Entities App:
    Open the Manage Entities app in BN4L Dock Appointment Scheduling.
  2. Define Recurring Block Times:
    Select your loading point and choose the ‚ÄúRecurring Block Times‚Äù option. Specify the recurrence pattern (daily, weekly, monthly), start/end times, and a description.
  3. Save and Apply:
    Once saved, these blocks will automatically appear in your dock appointment schedule, preventing bookings during the specified periods.
  4. Monitor and Adjust:
    Review blocked times in your scheduling overview and make adjustments as needed.

 

Sneak Preview 2511

Overview Video: Daily Recurring Block Series 2511

 

Creating a Recurring Block Series

Block Creation Options

  • Switching Between Block Types:
    You can choose to create either a Single Block or a Recurring Block. Select the desired option before proceeding with block configuration.

Configuring a Recurring Block Series

  1. Start and End Date/Time:
    Specify the start and end date and time for the recurring block series.
  2. Recurrence Interval:
    Define how often the block should repeat (e.g., every second day, weekly, monthly).
  3. Recurrence End Date:
    Set the end date for the recurring block series.

Notes on Recurring Blocks

  • If you select All Day Event, the start and end time fields will be disabled, and the entire day will be blocked.
  • For All Day Event blocks, ensure that the recurrence interval is not shorter than the duration of the block to prevent overlapping blocks.
  • All other settings are consistent for both Single and Recurring Block creation.

Capacity Settings

  • If you select Max. Capacity, the capacity input will be disabled, and the entire capacity for the loading point will be blocked.

Shipper View in Manage Dock Appointment: Calendar view

Shipper View in Manage Dock Appointment: Release a Single Block from the Series

Single blocks can be released using the Manage Dock Appointment App. Releasing a single block will free up the previously blocked capacity, making it available for new appointment bookings.

Note:
Releasing a single block does not impact any recurring block series that have been created for the loading point. Only the specific block is released, and the recurring series remains unchanged.

  • For shippers: Capacity becomes available for booking via the Manage Dock Appointment App.
  • For carriers: Capacity can be booked through the Self-Book Dock Appointments interface.

Block Creation - Capacity Check

When creating a Single or Recurring Block, the system automatically checks if sufficient appointment capacity is available for the selected date and time slot.

  • If there are existing blocks or booked appointments that overlap with the requested time, the system will prevent the creation of a new block if not enough remaining capacity is available that can be consumed by the new block.

Note:
If there is no available appointment capacity for the desired time slot, you must either release existing blocks or reschedule already booked appointments to free up capacity before creating a new block.

 

Further Information 

  • Release Schedule and Dates
  • What's New in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • What's New in the Test Tenants of SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration
  • Shipper Apps and APIs - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Carrier Apps and APIs - Self-Book Dock Appointments
  • Shipper APIs (SOAP APIs) - Dock Appointment Scheduling
  • Business Accelerator Hub - SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration (SOAP API)

entry.title: Re: How to batch upload G/L accounts in S/4 Public Cloud...
entry.content:
Hi @Grace_Li1,

Thanks very much for your question. There are a couple of things going on here.

First, the ‚ÄúNot Used‚Äù flag is obsolete within the Renumber G/L Accounts configuration activity. You should instead use the Implementation Status feature to mark accounts as not used.

As far as batching, there is no inbuilt batching mechanism. If you want to batch your G/L account uploads, then just go ahead and separate them into discrete files and upload the mapping data and the descriptions for each self-made batch as normal. You can batch them by delivered ID, account type, account group, or whatever other way makes the most sense for you. Just be sure to also update the mapping descriptions as well.

Finally, to maintain the accounts that weren‚Äôt automatically updated, you should use the Manage G/L Accounts Master Data app. This app will make it substantially easier to handle this.

Thank you!
